text.tspan: Rise of Boys’ Love Manga
Boys’ Love Manga became more popular and widely written
in the 1970s, at the same time that female artists began
taking over the shojo genre. Initially, these stories of love be
tween male characters were not sexual, and were known as
shonen-ai. In the late 1970s and early 1980s, more sexually
explicit stories were published, and were known as yaoi.
Kaze tells the story of the lives of and relationship between
two boys living in the city of Provence, France in the early
19th century. This sets the stage for many following yaoi
which also take place in far-off European cities in history, al
lowing readers to transport themselves to a different time and
place.
As you can see in the spread on the next pages, Kaze is very
visually interesting and “breaks all the rules,” like other
manga in the shojo genre. Additonally, the protagonists,
Serge and Gilbert, are androgynous, with long, thin limbs, flat
chests, and feminine faces with large, expressive eyes and
prominent eyelashes. Kaze is sited as the groundbreaking
first manga with explicit homosexual themes.
First Yaoi: Kaze to Ki no Uta
“The Poem of the Wind and the Trees”
by Keiko Takemiya
